On Mon, 19 Nov 2012 00:18:55 +0000 Stephen Connolly
<stephen.alan.connolly@=
gmail.com> wrote:

> > But it totally breaks encapsulation.
> >
> >
> No it=
 doesn't.
> 
> Explain how comparing objects based on the results of the ob=
jects
> public getters being the same breaks encapsulation? That is what I
=
> mean by duck-comparison: comparing based on what you can see using
> the =
public exposed API.

I'm with C=C3=A8dric on this one.

Adding getters (and=
 especially setters) for all fields is a code smell
to me. (The only except=
ion is for beans where you have to have them.)

I'd rather implement equals=
 and hashCode than add getters for the test.
If other code needs getters fo=
r every detail of the class, you're
probably violating Tell Don't Ask or ha=
ve some serious Feature Envy.

Just curious: doesn't that lead to multiple =
implementations of the
comparison easily when more than one test needs it?
=

Robert
